content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata> <idinfo> <datsetid>gov.noaa.coops:meteorological_observations</datsetid> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>Department of Commerce (DOC), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS)</origin> <pubdate>2009</pubdate> <title>CO-OPS Meteorological Observations Data</title> <geoform>map,graphic plots, tabular digital data</geoform> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Silver Spring, MD</pubplace> <publish>DOC/NOAA/NOS/CO-OPS > Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services, National Ocean Service, NOAA, U.S. Department of Commerce</publish> </pubinfo> <onlink>http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/stations.html?type=Meteorological%20Observations</onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>The National Ocean Service (NOS) maintains a long-term database containing a listing of active stations that are installed all over the United States and U.S. territories.                                                                                                                                          Water Levels observations, coastal currents and other meteorological and oceanographic data are monitored from a network of over 200 permanent, continuously operating stations and from numerous stations operated for short-term and long-term projects.                                                                                                        Stations are configured for a variety of observation periods, depending upon the location. For some stations, records date back to the late 1800s. Observed water level, ancillary and meteorological values are disseminated primarily at six minute increments. In addition, some stations provide real-time data for planning and emergency situations. The observed values are processed, stored and distributed over a wide variety of applications. The products are distributed on either hard copy, floppy disk, CD, or over the web and include the following:                                                                           Active Station Lists , Tide Observation , Wind data , Air Temperature data , Water Temperature data , Barometric Pressure data , Conductivity data , Humidity data , Air Gap data , Currents data , Other Meteorological and or ancillary data.</abstract> <purpose>The Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS) installs, maintains      active stations that collect real-time observations, coastal currents and other meteorological and oceanographic      data. More information can be obtained at http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/about.html</purpose> <supplinf>Many water level stations are equipped with meteorological sensors to collect      meteorological observations in conjunction with water level data. The following observations, wind speed and directions, air temperature, water temperature,      barometric pressure, relative humidity and conductivity/salinity may be retrieved from this website http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov .</supplinf> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <rngdates> <begdate>18540630</begdate> <enddate>Present</enddate> </rngdates> </timeinfo> <current>ground <useconst>Preliminary  Data        Preliminary data have not been subjected to the National Ocean Service's quality control or quality assurance      procedures and do not meet the criteria and standards of official National Ocean Service data. They are released for      limited public use as preliminary data to be used only with appropriate caution.</useconst> <ptcontac> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), Center for  Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS)</cntorg> </cntorgp> <cntpos>Chief, Products and Services Division (CO-OPS)</cntpos> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing and physical</addrtype> <address>1305 East-West Highway  N/OPS3</address> <city>Silver Spring</city> <state>MD</state> <postal>20910</postal> <country>U.S.A.</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>301-713-2981</cntvoice> <cnttdd>301-713-0296</cnttdd> <cntfax>301-713-4392</cntfax> <hours>0900 - 1700, Monday to Friday, EST</hours> </cntinfo> </ptcontac> <datacred>NOAA's Ocean Service, CO-OPS</datacred> </idinfo> <dataqual> <logic>Raw data have not been subjected to the National Ocean Service's quality control or quality assurance procedures and do not meet the criteria and standards of official National Ocean Service data. They are released for limited public use as preliminary data to be used only with appropriate caution.</complete> <lineage> <srcinfo> <srccite> <citeinfo> <origin>National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS)</origin> <pubdate>Unknown</pubdate> <title>CO-OPS Meteorological Data</title> <geoform>digital data</geoform> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Silver Spring, MD</pubplace> <publish>DOC/NOAA/NOS/CO-OPS > Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services, National Ocean Service, NOAA, U.S. Department of Commerce</publish> </pubinfo> <othercit>CO-OPS Data Disclaimer: These raw data have not been subjected to the National Ocean Service's quality control or      quality assurance procedures and do not meet the criteria and standards of official National Ocean Service data. They      are released for limited public use as preliminary data to be used only with appropriate caution.</othercit> <onlink>http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/</onlink> <onlink>http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/pub.html</onlink> </citeinfo> </srccite> <typesrc>online</typesrc> <srctime> <timeinfo> <rngdates> <begdate>1990</begdate> <enddate>Present</enddate> </rngdates> </timeinfo> <srccurr>ground condition</srccurr> </srctime> <srccitea>6minMetData</srccitea> <srccontr>The Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS) and its predecessors have gathered oceanographic data along our nation's coasts for over 200 years to protect life, property, and the environment. Serving both the public and other government agencies, CO-OPS is the authoritative source for accurate, reliable, and timely water-level and current measurements that support safe and efficient maritime commerce, sound coastal management, and recreation. The combined efforts, knowledge, and experience of CO-OPS's technicians, scientists, and engineers working to carry out a central mission has led to the development of a reliable center of expertise for coastal physical oceanography.</srccontr> </srcinfo> <procstep> <procdesc>Data is recorded and transmitted then is loaded into      a database, the raw data are then archived on a weekly basis in xml format</procdesc> <srcused>6minMetData</srcused> <procdate>Not Complete</procdate> </procstep> </lineage> </dataqual> <eainfo> <detailed> <enttyp> <enttypl>Station</enttypl> <enttypd>The geographic location at which tidal observations are conducted. Also, the facilities used to make tidal observations. These may include a tide house, tide (water level) gauge, tide staff, and tidal bench marks.      See primary control tide station, secondary control tide station, tertiary tide station, and subordinate tide station.</enttypd> <enttypds>http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/pub.html        http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/publications/CO-OPS_Specifications_and_Deliverables_for_installation_operation_and_removal_of_water_level_stations_updated_October_2013.pdf        http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/publications/Standing_Project_Instructions_for_Coastal_and_Great_Lakes_Water_Level_Stations_Updated_October_2013.pdf        http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/publications/CY2014PIs_1_28_2014_FINAL.pdf</enttypds> </enttyp> <attr> <attrlabl>Station Id</attrlabl> <attrdef>Unique ID given to the Station where instrument was deployed.</attrdef> <attrdefs>DOC/NOAA/NOS/COOPS > Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS), National      Ocean Service (NOS), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC)</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <rdom> <rdommin>0</rdommin> <rdommax>9999999</rdommax> <attrunit>numbers</attrunit> </rdom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>STATION NAME</attrlabl> <attrdef>Station name is the general-purpose      identifier for the station. It can be up to 80 alphanumeric characters.</attrdef> <attrdefs>DOC/NOAA/NOS/COOPS >      Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS), National Ocean Service (NOS), National Oceanic      and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC)</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>Values do not      exist in a predefined set</udom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Station Datum</attrlabl> <attrdef>For      marine applications, a base elevation used as a reference from which to reckon heights or depths. It is called a      tidal datum when defined in terms of a certain phase of the tide. Tidal datums are local datums  and should not be      extended into areas which have differing hydrographic characteristics without substantiating measurements. In order      that they may be recovered when needed, such datums are referenced to fixed points known as bench marks.          For more information on Station: http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/station_retrieve.shtml?type=Bench+Mark+Data+Sheets</attrdef> <attrdefs>DOC/NOAA/NOS/COOPS > Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS), National      Ocean Service (NOS), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC)</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <rdom> <rdommin>-100</rdommin> <rdommax>+100</rdommax> <attrunit>meters</attrunit> </rdom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Latitude</attrlabl> <attrdef>Latitude is measured from the equator,      with positive values going north and negative values going south.</attrdef> <attrdefs>NASA</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <rdom> <rdommin>-90 Precision WGS 84: 4 digits to right of decimal will approximate +/-10 meters in resolution</rdommin> <rdommax>+90 Precision WGS 84: 4 digits to right of decimal will approximate +/-10 meters in resolution</rdommax> <attrunit>degree minutes</attrunit> </rdom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Longitude</attrlabl> <attrdef>Longitude is measured from the Prime Meridian (which is the longitude that runs through Greenwich, England), with positive values going east and negative values going west.</attrdef> <attrdefs>NASA</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <rdom> <rdommin>-180 Precision WGS 84: 4 digits to right of decimal will approximate +/-10 meters in      resolution</rdommin> <rdommax>+180 Precision WGS 84: 4 digits to right of decimal will approximate +/-10 meters in      resolution</rdommax> <attrunit>degree minutes</attrunit> </rdom> </attrdomv> data, stores the data in random access memory (RAM), and      provides communication links for the retrieval or transmission of the data.</enttypd> <enttypds>http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/publications/NextGenerationWaterLevelMeasurementSystemMANUAL.pdf      http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/publications/Xpert_User_Manual.pdf</enttypds> </enttyp> <attr> <attrlabl>DCP#</attrlabl> <attrdef>Unique ID given to the dcp</attrdef> <attrdefs>DOC/NOAA/NOS/COOPS</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <rdom> <rdommin>1</rdommin> <rdommax>3</rdommax> <attrunit>numbers</attrunit> </rdom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Time</attrlabl> <attrdef>The coordinated universal Time stamp at which the water level was recorded. It is in the format HH24MMSSZ</attrdef> <attrdefs>DOC/NOAA/NOS/COOPS > Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS),      National Ocean Service (NOS), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), U.S. Department of Commerce      (DOC)</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <rdom> <rdommin>000000Z</rdommin> <rdommax>235959Z</rdommax> <attrunit>UTC</attrunit> </rdom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>date</attrlabl> <attrdef>The calendar date on which the      data was collected. It is in the format YYYYMMDD</attrdef> <attrdefs>DOC/NOAA/NOS/COOPS</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <rdom> <rdommin>19000101</rdommin> <rdommax>unbounded</rdommax> <attrunit>Days</attrunit> </rdom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Water Level</attrlabl> <attrdef>The water level value as collected and diseminated by the dcp.</attrdef> <attrdefs>DOC/NOAA/NOS/COOPS</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <rdom> <rdommin>-100.000</rdommin> <rdommax>+100.000</rdommax> <attrunit>meters</attrunit> </rdom> </attrdomv> </attr> </detailed> </eainfo> <distinfo> <distrib> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and      Services (CO-OPS)</cntorg> </cntorgp> <cntpos>Chief, Products and Services Division (CO-OPS)</cntpos> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing and physical</addrtype> <address>1305 East-West Highway N/OPS3</address> <city>Silver Spring</city> <state>MD</state> <postal>20910</postal> <country>U.S.A.</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>301-713-2981</cntvoice> <cnttdd>301-713-0296</cnttdd> <cntfax>301-713-4392</cntfax> <hours>0900 - 1700, Monday to Friday, EST</hours> </cntinfo> </distrib> <resdesc>Downloadable Data</resdesc> <distliab>Preliminary data have not been subjected to the National Ocean Service's quality control or quality assurance procedures and do not meet the criteria and standards of official National Ocean Service data. They are released for limited public use as preliminary data to be used only with appropriate caution. NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of  the data to function on a particular system.      NOAA makes no warranty, expressed or implied, nor does the fact of distribution constitute such a warranty.</distliab> <stdorder> <digform> <digtinfo> <formname>ASCII</formname> </digtinfo> <digtopt> <onlinopt> <computer> <networka> <networkr>http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/stations.html?type=Meteorological%20Observations</networkr> <networkr>http://opendap.co-ops.nos.noaa.gov/ioos-dif-sos/</networkr> <networkr>http://opendap.co-ops.nos.noaa.gov/axis/</networkr> </networka> </computer> </onlinopt> <offoptn> <offmedia>CD-ROM</offmedia> <recfmt>Data burned to CD-ROM</recfmt> </offoptn> </digtopt> </digform> <fees>There is      a fee for services rendered by CO-OPS. A request for water level data, benchmark information, Great Lakes data and      information typically costs $48.00.</fees> </stdorder> </distinfo> <metainfo> <metd>20141112</metd> <metrd>20141112</metrd> <metc> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Ocean Service (NOS), Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS)</cntorg> </cntorgp> <cntpos>Chief, Products and      Services Division (CO-OPS)</cntpos> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing and physical</addrtype> <address>1305 East-West      Highway N/OPS3</address> <city>Silver Spring</city> <state>MD</state> <postal>20910</postal> <country>U.S.A.</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>301-713-2981</cntvoice> <cnttdd>301-713-0296</cnttdd> <cntfax>301-713-4392</cntfax> <hours>0900 - 1700, Monday to Friday, EST</hours> </cntinfo> </metc> <metstdn>FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata</metstdn> <metstdv>FGDC-STD-012-2002</metstdv> <mettc>universal time</mettc> <metextns> <onlink>http://www.ncddc.noaa.gov/metadata-standards/documents/ncddcmdprofile_v2.pdf</onlink> <metprof>Content Specification for Metadata in the National Coastal Data Development Center's Data Catalog Version 2.0</metprof> </metextns> </metainfo> <plmiinfo> <missinfo> <missdesc>The Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS) of the National Ocean      Service (NOS), an organizational element of NOAA, operates and maintains a network of approximately 200 long-term      National Water Level Observation Network (NWLON) stations as part of the National Water Level Program (NWLP) for the      United States coast and in the Great Lakes.  CO-OPS installs and operates short-term water level stations in support      of a variety of programs including hydrographic surveys, marine boundary determination, habitat restoration,      dredging, climate change, and long-term sea level rise studies.  CO-OPS collects current data as a part of the      National Currents Observation Program (NCOP) at locations throughout the United States.  The data collected and      predictions derived are used to ensure safe, efficient, and environmentally sound maritime commerce.  CO-OPS provides      a set of water level and coastal current products.  These include data and products required by NOAA's National      Weather Service (NWS) to meet flood and tsunami warning responsibilities and a national network of Physical      Oceanographic Real-Time Systems (PORTS) in major United States harbors. The Meteorological data is collected and  transmitted every 6 minutes via Geostationary Observing Environmental Satellites (GOES)      utilizing special data collection platforms.             CO-OPS is the authoritative source for accurate, reliable, and timely tides, water levels, currents and other oceanographic information. Our data, products and services support safe and efficient navigation, sound ecosystem stewardship, coastal hazards preparedness and response, and the understanding of climate change.             The Center for Operational Products and Services (CO-OPS) of NOS contributes to this mission by providing timely and accurate tide and current information. These data are produced by the National Water Level Observation Network (NWLON)      For more information visit:http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/about.html</missdesc> <misshist> <missstdt> <sngdate> <caldate>1807</caldate> </sngdate> </missstdt> <misssige> <procstep> <procdesc>PORTS began in 1991 as a demonstration project to prove the value of real-time informationto the marinenavigation community. PORTS systems come in a variety of sizes and configurations, each specificallydesigned to meet local user requirements. The largest ofNOS' existingPORTS installations is comprisedof more than 26 separate instruments. The smallest consist of a single water level gauge and associatedmeteorological instruments (i.e., winds, barometric pressure, etc.).The objectives of the PORTS program are to: promote navigation safety, improve the efficiency of U.S.ports and harbors, and ensure the protection of coastal marine resources. For More information http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/ports.html</procdesc> <procdate>1991</procdate> </procstep> </misssige> <misssige> <procstep> <procdesc>The primary objective of the National Operational Coastal Modeling Program (NOCMP) is to develop a national network of Operational Nowcast and Forecast Hydrodynamic Model Systems (called OFS) to support NOAA's mission goals and priorities.An OFS consists of the automated integration of observing system data streams, hydrodynamic model predictions, product dissemination and continuous quality-control monitoring. State-of-the-art numerical hydrodynamic models driven by real-time data and model forecast guidance will form the core of these end-to-end systems. The OFS will perform nowcast and short-term (0 hr. - 48 hr.)forecast predictions of pertinent parameters (e.g., water-levels, currents, salinity, temperature, waves) and disseminate them to users. For More information:http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/nocmp.html</procdesc> <procdate>Unknown</procdate> </procstep> </misssige> <misssige> <procstep> <procdesc>Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS) manages the National Current Observation Program (NCOP) to collect, analyze, and distribute observations and predictions of currents. The program's goals are to ensure safe, efficient and environmentally sound maritime commerce, and to support environmental needs such as HAZMAT response. The principal product generated by this program is information used to maintain and update the Tidal Current Tables.For More information: http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/ncop.html</procdesc> <procdate>1990</procdate> </procstep> </misssige> </misshist> </missinfo> <platinfo> <platstdt> <sngdate> <caldate>Unknown</caldate> </sngdate> </platstdt> <platspon>NOAA's Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS)</platspon> <platdesc>Coastal tide stations set up to receive water level and meteorological data collected by      various sensor, stored in DCP, transmitted via GOES satellite and ingested by CO-OPS database.</platdesc> </platinfo> </plmiinfo> <instinfo> <instdesc> <insttyp>Yellow Springs Instruments</insttyp> <opmode>Time based 6 minutes samples for  (PORTS) and  Hourly for  (NWLON)</opmode> <colltype>20 equally spaced samples collected over a 2 minute period are averaged for each measurement. The samples are collected starting one minute prior to each tenth hour at PORTS sites or centered on the hour otherwise.</colltype> <othcolde>Estimated Accuracy: +/- 0.2 Deg.C ; Resolution 0.1 Deg.C</othcolde> </instdesc> </instinfo> <instinfo> <instdesc> <insttyp>Yellow Springs Instruments</insttyp> <opmode>Time based 6 minutes samples for  (PORTS) and  Hourly for  (NWLON)</opmode> <colltype>20 equally spaced samples collected over a 2 minute period are averaged for each measurement. The samples are collected starting one minute prior to each tenth hour at PORTS sites or centered on the hour otherwise.</colltype> <othcolde>Estimated Accuracy: +/- 0.2 Deg.C ; Resolution 0.1 Deg.C</othcolde> </instdesc> </instinfo> <instinfo> <instdesc> <insttyp>R.M. Young Model 05103</insttyp> <opmode>Time based 6 minutes samples for  (PORTS) and  Hourly for  (NWLON)</opmode> <colltype>Speed - 2 minute scalar average of 1 second wind speed measurements collected prior to each tenth hour.Wind Direction - 2 minute unit vector average of wind direction collected prior to each tenth hour.Wind Gust - The maximum 5 second moving scalar average of wind speed that occurred during the previous 6 minutes for PORTS stations, during the previous hour otherwise.</colltype> <othcolde>Typically installed approximate 10 m above sea level ; Estimated Accuracy: Speed +/- 0.3 m/sec. Direction +/- 3 Deg.(Speed Threshold 1 m/sec) ; Resolution Speed 0.1 m/sec. Direction 0.1 Deg.</othcolde> </instdesc> </instinfo> <instinfo> <instdesc> <insttyp>Setra , Vaisala, or Sutron Acubar</insttyp> <opmode>Time based 6 minutes samples for  (PORTS) and  Hourly for  (NWLON)</opmode> <colltype>20 equally spaced samples collected over a 2 minute period are averaged for each measurement. The samples are collected starting one minute prior to each tenth hour at PORTS sites or centered on the hour otherwise.</colltype> <othcolde>Estimated Accuracy: +/- 0.5 mbar ; Resolution 0.1 mbar</othcolde> </instdesc> </instinfo> </metadata>
